title-group.article-title: Constructal design of multiple heat sources in a square-shaped fin

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Reza Hajmohammadi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran. Email: mh.hajmohammadi@yahoo.com

abstract.p: A new study area of constructal theory is presented by applying constructal design on multiple heat sources which connected to and cooled in a square-shaped fin. Analyzing the optimal location of the heat sources in the fin for several configurations is the primary goal of this study. According to the constructal theory, favorable distribution of the heat sources is achieved by minimizing the global thermal resistance of the fin body. Since the heat sources might be contemplated as heat-generating electronic bodies or hot-water pipes, two boundary conditions of uniform heat flux and uniform temperature are considered for the heat sources. The minimization of the thermal resistance in the uniform heat flux and uniform temperature cases leads to the minimization of the hot spot temperature and the maximization of the total heat removal, respectively. Temperature fields in the square-shaped fin are calculated using a finite element approach of MATLAB PDE Toolbox. The optimized configurations are numerically compared with each other. It is shown that the most commonly used configurations of the heat sources in a cooling industry are unfavorable and must be avoided. Favorable configurations such as triangular arrangement of heat sources are proposed to replace the unfavorable configurations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The natural tendency of flow with the best possible configuration means how to optimally distribute imperfection throughout the flow, so that it moves best with the least loss and dissipation; in other words, it moves within the least expensive route. This is the essential concept of constructal theory that states ‘for a finite-size system to persist in time, it must evolve in such a way that provides easier access to the imposed currents flowing through it.’1 Using constructal theory, this natural behavior can be conceived as a phenomenon of configuration generation. Constructal theory has been proposed, because of its applicability to natural and engineering flow systems, and much research has been done based on this theory.

In fluid mechanics, tree-shaped networks have been proposed to obtain less possible pressure drop in a flow system.1,2 Constructal theory was also used in thermodynamics; it posed novel approaches to improve thermodynamically the performance of a flowing system. For example, employing constructal theory, several classes of simple flow systems consisting of T- and Y-shaped assemblies of ducts, channels, and streams in a laminar and fully developed flow regime were studied. They demonstrated how the minimum entropy generation can be obtained.3
Regarding really effective and simple principles of this theory, many scientists have applied this theory to present optimal designs in engineering.

During the past decades, constructal theory has been applied by many researchers so as to improve the performance of heat transfer systems. Rocha et al.4 showed how to optimally insert a high-conductivity tree-shaped structure into a round heat-generating body so as to cool it best. Bello-Ochende and Bejan5 studied on the optimal spacing between the plates in a heat-generating stack of parallel plates constrained with a fixed volume and presented a single formula for optimum spacing between the plates in a pure natural, pure forced, and mixed convection flow system.

The design of fins was another area where constructal design was applied. The best configuration of fins has been studied by several authors6–11 under different circumstances. Alebrahim and Bejan6 explored the optimization of circular fins that enhanced both conductive and convective heat transfer. Almogbel and Bejan7,8 did a research in maximizing the overall conductance of cylindrical and T-shaped assemblies of pin fins subjected to fixed total volume and the amount of fin material as well. Constructal design of fins was discussed further under different constraints, mechanisms of heat transfer, and applications such as heat exchangers and led up to valuable results.8–11

Another issue that attracted the attention of researchers was constructal design of the ‘cavities’ which is very similar to the fin design.12–16 For example, Rocha et al.12 minimized the overall thermal resistance between the whole system (cavity and solid) and the surroundings for a rectangular cavity with fixed volume and variable aspect ratio in a trapezoidal solid conducting wall. Furthermore, Biserni13 carried out a numerical research on insertion of an H-shaped cavity with isothermal surfaces into a solid conducting wall which uniformly generated heat and was adiabatic on the outer surfaces. The total volume and also the volume of the H-shaped cavity were considered fixed; however, cavity geometry was free to change. It was observed that the performance of the H-shaped cavity is better than the C-shaped, T-shaped, and rectangular cavities. Lorenzini and Rocha14 focused on a T–Y-shaped cavity in a rectangular, solid, conducting wall with uniform heat generation on the solid wall. Both the total and cavity volume were considered fixed and the aspect ratios of the cavities varied. More recently, Xie et al.15 determined the optimal aspect ratios of a T-shaped cavity in a trapezoidal solid material with uniform heat generation by applying constructal theory.

Although several works have concentrated on the design of fin shape and structure for a given heat source configuration, the configuration of heat sources in a given fin shape has not yet been analyzed. Thanks to the prominent part of square and thin fins in the heat removal from equipment, especially in electronics; it is worthy to concentrate on the distribution of the heat sources in a square-shaped fin to fill the present gap in the field.

In this article, constructal design is applied employing a two-step optimization procedure to determine the optimal distribution of multiple heat sources cooled in a square-shaped fin. In the first step, different heat source configurations are considered, and the optimal location of the heat sources is obtained for each configuration in the considered fin body. In the next step, the optimized configurations from the previous step are compared to each other to determine the configuration with the best thermal performance. The optimization objective is to minimize the hot spot temperature of the fin body when heat is removed from the heat sources to the fin at uniform heat flux, (UH case) such as electronic chips with low conductivity relative to that of the fin or a rotating shaft with uniform friction on the perimeter. The optimization objective is also to maximize the total heat removal from the heat sources when heat is removed from the heat source into the fin at a uniform temperature (UT case) such as a boiling fluid flowing through the pipe. The described optimization procedure is carried out using a finite element approach of MATLAB PDE Toolbox (PDE, partial differential equation) to numerically calculate the temperature fields in the fin. Analyzing the optimization results obtained from the numerical solution, several strategies are proposed for optimal distribution of one, two, three, and four heat sources in a square-shaped fin.

To conclude this section, it is extremely important to mention how this research and, in general, how the new study area of constructal design can strategically result in application of extended surfaces for enhanced heat transfer.

sec.title: Problem definition
sec.p:
Geometry and coordinate system definition for a system of a thin square-shaped fin is shown in Figure 1. The two square-shaped surfaces of the fin paralleled to the x–y plane remove heat from circular-based walls of heat sources at uniform heat flux, q″, or uniform temperature, Th, to a cold free stream of temperature T∞. Heat-transfer coefficient, h, is considered to be uniform over all the exposed surfaces. The lateral surfaces of the fin body are insulated. The fin thickness, t, is assumed to be sufficiently small in comparison with the fin height and width, H, such that temperature of the fin body can be supposed to be uniform in the z-direction and only varies in x- and y-directions. Figure 1.
Geometry and coordinate system definition for a system of a thin square fin body and a circular-shaped heat source.

The schematic of several configurations for a different number of heat sources connected to the two-dimensional square-shaped fins is depicted in a tree-view in Figure 2. Dashed lines indicate the paths over which the heat sources can be located, and dotted ones, if any, divide the fins to symmetrical areas. The normal configurations, (2a), (3a), and (4a) in Figure 2, that include two, three and four heat sources located in a row or in a column, are commonly used in practice. It is later shown that the foregoing configurations are unfavorable in comparison with the others shown in Figure 2 of the same number of heat sources. The location of the heat sources is determined by e, which is the center-to-center distance of the fin and the heat sources. As observed in Figure 2, by increasing the number of the heat sources, the diversity of the configurations grows up. In each configuration, optimization analysis is carried out for two cases, UH and UT. Two distinct purposes of the optimization are pursued; minimizing the hot spot temperature in the UH case and maximizing the total heat removal in the UT case. The optimizing procedure consists of two steps. First, the optimal value of e is determined in each configuration of Figure 2. Then, the optimal configurations obtained in the previous step are compared to each other. In order to perform the described optimization procedure, it is necessary to formulate the problem. Figure 2.
Tree-view of different configurations for different number of heat sources attached and cooled through a square-shaped fin body.

sec.title: Mathematical formulation
sec.p: Considering the limitations of space, weight, and cost of the materials, the total volume occupied by the body, V, is considered as fixed for a given fin. The total area occupied by the fin body, A = H2, is also considered as fixed as well as the total volume and the total area occupied by the heat sources, Vc and Ac, respectively, for the space considerations. The foregoing constraints can be expressed by the following relation (1)ϕ=Vc/V=Ac/A=nπR2H2=const where φ represents the volume fraction occupied by the heat sources, n the number of heat sources, and R the radius of the circular-shaped heat sources. Fins are considered as isotropic solids with uniform thermal conductivity, k. The governing energy equation for the temperature field of the fin body in a steady-state condition is (2)∂2T∂x2+∂2T∂y2+∂2T∂z2=0
Assuming the uniform temperature of the fin body in z-direction and integrating equation (2) from z = 0 to z = t, equation (2) can be rewritten as (3)∂2T∂x2+∂2T∂y2-2hkt(T-T∞)=0

The following dimensionless variables are defined as (4)θ=T-T∞q″A1/2/k (5)(x~,y~,r~,R~,H~,e~,s~)=(x,y,r,R,H,e,s)A1/2 where x and y are Cartesian coordinates r and s normal and tangential coordinates to circular-shaped boundaries of the heat sources perimeter, respectively, and θ the dimensionless temperature. The energy equation (3) can now be expressed in the dimensionless form (6)∂2θ∂x~2+∂2θ∂y~2-2aθ=0 where (7)a=hAkt

In this study, the parameter, a, emerged in equation (6), and the parameter φ are considered as 25 and 0.1, respectively, which, in the order of magnitude sense, agree with practical values used by industry. For example, in forced convection to gas flow, the order of magnitude of h is 102 W/m2 K, while the thermal conductivities of aluminum and copper are of the order 102 W/m K and A ∼ 0.1 m2.8 the foregoing values, Ac ∼ 0.01 m2 and t ∼ 5 mm in equation (7), leads to the results a ∼ 20 and φ ∼ 10−1. The optimization objectives can be expressed in the dimensionless form as the minimization of (10)θmax=Tmax-T∞q″A1/2/k in the UH case and the maximization of (11)C=Qkt(Th-T∞)=(1/θh)∮c∂θ∂r~ds~ in the UT case. C represents the global thermal conductance of the fin body and c the closed circular-shaped boundaries on the heat source perimeter.

sec.title: Solution
sec.p: Numerical study consists of determining the temperature field in a large number of configurations of the type shown in Figure 2. The governing PDE (6), is solved numerically using a finite element approach of PDE Toolbox of MATLAB16 which converts the PDE (6) into the system of discrete algebraic equations based on triangular elements. The grid is considered non-uniform in both x~ and y~, and varied from one geometry to the next. The appropriate mesh size is determined by the successive refinements, increasing the number of elements four times from the current mesh size to the next mesh size, until the criterion |(θmaxj-θmaxj+1)/θmaxj|<2×10-5 is satisfied. Here, θmaxj stands for the hot spot temperature calculated using the current mesh size and θmaxj+1 for the hot spot temperature calculated using the next mesh size where the number of elements is increased by four times. The optimization results are calculated using a range between 10,000 and 78,000 triangular elements. A similar grid independence study is performed for calculating C (equation (11)).

For the validation of the present numerical simulation, the hot spot temperature in a similar case study (Figure 3) is calculated from the present numerical study and compared with the exact solution17 in Table 1. The case study shown in Figure 3 consists of a pin fin body which removes heat at circular-based boundary, r = R, with uniform heat flux. Comparison between the two solutions reveals an excellent agreement. Figure 3.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this section, the results of the optimal distribution (location and configuration) of multiple heat sources cooled in the square-shaped fin are presented and discussed. Applying the principle of uniform distribution of imperfections stated in constructal law,1 the optimal distribution in configurations (1), (2a), (3a), (4a), and (4b) in Figure 2 can be easily (without optimization analysis) achieved. In fact, for the foregoing configurations, the optimal distribution is obtained when the fin area is divided into symmetrical divisions and the heat sources are located at the center of the divisions. For the remaining configurations, namely (2b), (3b), (3c), (4c), and (4d), optimization analysis is carried out by performing a numerical solution to determine the optimal location of the heat sources. The results of the optimization analysis for the two cases, UH and UT, and for different configurations are presented in the following sections.

sec.title: UH case
sec.p:
Figures 4 to 6 show the effect of two, three and four heat sources location, e, respectively, on the hot spot temperature, θmax, for different configurations of Figure 2. It can be observed that for every configuration, there is an optimal e, which minimizes the hot spot temperature. For each configuration, there is also an allowable range of e, such that all the heat sources can correctly fit in the fin body. Figure 7 shows the effect of e2, the first geometrical parameter free to change, on the hot spot temperature for configuration (4d) for several values of e1, which is the second geometrical parameter free to change. Figure 7 reveals that there is an alternative opportunity of optimization. Therefore, the results shown in Figure 7 are summarized in Figure 8, where the optimal value of e2 namely (e2)o and the minimized hot spot temperature, θmax)min, calculated in Figure 7, are plotted as a function of e1. It should be noted that the subscript ‘min’ means that θmax is minimized with respect to e2. The curves that partially overlapped with other (such as the curves shown in Figures 4, 5, and 7) show that the effect of configuration on the hot spot temperature can be disregarded in some ranges of e. It is also worth noting that analyzing the temperature contours in the fin body obtained from the numerical solution revealed that when the values of e approach to the optimum value, eo, the location of the hot spot is changed from one position to another, as depicted in Figure 9. Thus, for some cases observed in Figures 5 to 7, there is a discontinuity in the trend of hot spot temperature, θmax, in the minimum point. Figure 4.

The values of the optimal location of the heat sources in Figures 4 to 8 together with the corresponding hot spot temperature are listed in Table 2. From the comparison between the values of hot spot temperature in different configurations listed in Table 2, it can be seen that the optimal configurations for two, three and four heat sources are (2b), (3c), and (4b), respectively. On the contrary, the least efficient configurations (configurations with highest value of hot spot temperature) for two, three, and four heat sources are (2a), (3a), and (4a), respectively, which were already called as ‘normal’ configurations. The label of ‘min–min’ for the minimum hot spot temperature of the case (4d) in Table 2 means that it is minimized twice, i.e. with respect to both e1 and e2. Figure 8.

Hence, an analogous procedure for obtaining the results shown in Figure 5 is repeated for the case (3c), this time for heat sources of different radii. The results are plotted in Figure 10. sec.p:
Figures 11 to 13 show the effect of two, three, and four heat sources location, e, on the global thermal conductance of the fin body, C, (equation (11)) for several configurations of Figure 2. Figures 11 to 13 prove that for every configuration, there is an optimal e which maximizes C. The effect of e2 on the global thermal conductance of the fin body for configuration (4d) of Figure 2 is shown in Figure 14 for several values of e1. Figure 14 indicates that there is an alternative opportunity of optimization, and hence, the summarized results of Figure 14 are shown in Figure 15. Figure 11.

Comparing the values of Cmax in different configurations of Figure 2, it can be concluded that the optimal configurations for two, three, and four heat sources are (2b), (3c), and (4b), respectively. Comparing the optimized results (listed in Tables 2 and 3) to each other, it can be realized that the optimization results for the two different boundary conditions (UH and UT cases) are approximately the same, and thus, the optimized results are independent of the boundary condition considered for the heat sources. sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: This study applies the constructal design to address the optimal distribution of multiple heat sources which connected to and cooled in a square-shaped fin. Optimization process is carried out by performing a numerical analysis to calculate the temperature fields in the fin. The optimization objective is to distribute the heat sources throughout the fin body so that global thermal resistance of the fin is minimized.

The optimization analysis concluded that the regular configuration of the heat sources (such as row or columnar arrangements) which is frequently used in industry must be strongly avoided. This concern is more pronounced when the number of the heat sources is increased. For example, when the triangular distribution is compared with the regular distribution of three heat sources, it is shown that under the same thermal conditions and the same surface area of the fin, the triangular distribution is about 21% superior in reducing the thermal resistance of the fin body. The analysis also concluded that designing the heat sources of the same radius can be a more effective method in reducing the thermal resistance rather than designing the heat sources with different radii. Another helpful outcome of this study is that the optimization procedure predicts the same optimal distribution of the heat sources when different boundary conditions, UH case and UT case, are considered for the heat sources. Since the optimization procedure in the UH case is extremely superior than the UT case (higher accuracy and ease of calculations), the optimization outcomes obtained in the UH case can also be applied for the UT case in future works.

This study also deserves further investigations in the future; therefore, the effect of the heat sources and the fin shape, the aspect ratio of the fin body, and the parameters ‘a’ and ‘φ’ on thermal performance of the fin body, which were not addressed in this article, can be studied.
